newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian deficit prompts economic emergency.
newsitem.headline: Colombian deficit prompts economic emergency.

text.p: Colombia's President Ernesto Samper declared an economic emergency Monday to fight the central government's yawning fiscal deficit, national radio reported.
The emergency powers will last for an initial period of 30 days and can be extended for a maximum 90 days. The government deficit in 1996 was 4.0 percent of gross domestic product.
The country's main radio stations said Samper declared the emergency after a four-hour meeting with his cabinet. It is not yet clear what precise measures Samper will announce.

He is due to give a televised speech at 8 pm (0100 GMT) in which he is expected to address the issue. Finance Minister Jos Antonio Ocampo has called a press conference for 8:30 pm (0130 GMT) in which he is expected to announce specific measures.
Colombia's economic emergency laws give the president powers that include firing public sector employees en masse and cutting out layers of bureaucracy without the previous approval of Congress.
It is the second time an economic emergency has been declared since a new constitution was ratified in 1991.

President Csar Gaviria called an emergency in 1992 when many of the country's dams dried up, sparking severe power shortages. Some 80 percent of Colombia's electricity is generated by hydro-electric power.
